awd_titl_txt: Near-contact motion and coalescence of inertial droplets in turbulence: simulations, laboratory experiments and field measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Collins, Lance
Proposal Number: 1605195

A comprehensive research approach, involving high fidelity computations, experiments in a laboratory and field experiments is proposed to understand and predict the behavior of drops suspended in turbulent flows. This problem is very important for the behavior of clouds in the atmosphere. In addition to atmospheric applications, there are many other application areas with engineering interest, where this work can have an impact, including diesel engines, sprays, atomization, and powder manufacturing and inhalation drug therapy. 

Despite more than a half-century of research, there remains considerable uncertainty on how turbulence enhances the coalescence rate of suspended droplets. This study addresses that uncertainty through the direct measurement of droplet collision/coalescence rates in direct numerical simulations (DNS), experiments and in field measurements over a wide range of conditions. The focus of the study will be on the direct measurement of coalescence rates of droplets driven by turbulence. This has application to a wide range of multiphase flows, but the application of primary importance to this proposal is the processing of clouds in the atmosphere. Under certain conditions, clouds evolve faster than microphysical models can predict. It is believed that atmospheric turbulence could explain the acceleration of cloud formation. This study will bring together a synergistic combination of three scientific tools for analyzing natural turbulent flow phenomena: DNS; laboratory experiments; and field measurements. The overarching goal is to generate definitive coalescence data from high-resolution DNS and state-of-the-art laboratory and field experiments under conditions of near parametric similarity. This investigation will include the first experimental measurements of the coalescence rate for inertial droplets in a turbulent flow field, both in the laboratory and in natural conditions. Only with this collective effort can this be achieved - any one or two of these techniques alone will not sufficient. In addition to the engineering impacts of the proposed work, the proposed activities include educational and outreach activities that are targeted towards  encouraging underrepresented minorities into the academy.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this research project is to improve our ability to compute the effect of human activities on the Earth's climate. Climate change has profound implications on society and economies that extend well beyond the academic world. Clouds have an outsized impact on the our ability to predict climate change, due to their turbulent natures and our uncertainty about how to model them. Warm clouds are composed of tiny liquid water droplets suspended in the air, and the lifetime of these clouds is determine by the fate of its constituent droplets. One particularly important fate is the collision and coalescence of droplets into larger ones that ultimately fall out of the clouds. Because the microscopically small process of droplet coalescence depends on conditions generated by much larger turbulent and atmospheric motions, it is difficult to study. To understand the process, we brought together state-of-the-art laboratory experiments, computer simulations, and field measurements to study the near-contact motions and coalescence rates of water droplets suspended in air. In the laboratory, we developed and validated methods with the so-far unique ability to track the positions of nearby cloud droplets in three dimensions and through time up until the moment of the coalescence of two droplets. The new methods were applied to study the dynamics of droplets pairs close enough to each other that we could detect the escape of the last bits of air between the droplets. We found that we could characterize the droplet dynamics in terms of the relative accelerations of the droplets, and that we could assess the way the process of squeezing air out from between droplets determined the fate of the droplets pairs: whether they coalesced or not. With the same methods, we also discovered how electrical charges on droplets qualitatively change the way droplets coalesce. Theoretically, we developed a new and generalized formulation for the forces and torques experienced by two droplets at arbitrary separations and including separations so small that the air needs to be treated as individual molecules rather than as a continuum as is standard hydrodynamic theories. Using this theory, we showed how this last regime of rarefied air needs to be incorporated into the theory in order to predict from first principles that coalescence occurs at all — the standard hydrodynamic theories predict that coalescence should not occur under the conditions that prevail in atmospheric clouds. Finally, we advanced the highly parallel particle-laden flow solver for turbulence research (HIPPSTR, a parallel code for solving the fluid and particle equations on a periodic cube). We added a collision-optimized detection algorithm (CODA) to enact collisions and coalescence in the parallel code environment. Using the code, we performed computer simulations of collision and coalescence to find how the size distribution of droplets changed as a function of the intensity of the turbulence in the cloud. The experimental methods, theoretical expressions, and computer codes that result from this research project describe hydrodynamic interactions between droplets and other spherical particles. As such they are widely applicable, for example to soot particles in flames, to powder manufacturing processes, to the early stages of the formation of planets, and to aerosol drug delivery, in addition to the problem that initially motivated us: that of atmospheric cloud evolution and its relation to the modeling of the climate and the prediction of its evolution.
